content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students conduct an experiment to verify the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>. The group places a cart with very small wheels at one end of a horizontal section of a track that smoothly transitions into a sloped section as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A force is momentarily exerted on the cart, after which the cart moves with a constant speed toward the sloped section. All frictional forces are negligible.

(a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that can be graphed to determine the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students conduct an experiment to verify the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>. The group places a cart with very small wheels at one end of a horizontal section of a track that smoothly transitions into a sloped section as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. A force is momentarily exerted on the cart, after which the cart moves with a constant speed toward the sloped section. All frictional forces are negligible.

(a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that can be graphed to determine the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

(b) Describe how the data collected in part (a) could be graphed and describe how that graph would be analyzed to determine the magnitude of the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>g</mi></math>.

In a second experiment, the group attaches a fan to the top of the cart and places the fan-cart system on an inclined track where the angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> of the track above the horizontal can be adjusted as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The group is to experimentally determine the magnitude of the force <math alttext="F sub F" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></msub></math> exerted by air on the fan-cart. The force of air exerted on the fan-cart may be assumed to always be parallel to the motion of the fan-cart. The group measures the mass of the fan-cart to be <math alttext="0.30 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.30</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>.

The following table contains data of the acceleration of the fan-cart when the track is set to different angles above the horizontal.

Angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math>
 Acceleration <math alttext="a, in meters per second squared" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><msup><mtext>m/s</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math>

<math alttext="5 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></math>
 <math alttext="negative 0.1" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>0.1</mn></math>

<math alttext="10 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></math>
 <math alttext="negative 1.0" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>1.0</mn></math>

<math alttext="15 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></math>
 <math alttext="negative 1.8" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>1.8</mn></math>

<math alttext="20 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></math>
 <math alttext="negative 2.6" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>2.6</mn></math>

<math alttext="25 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">°</mi></math>
 <math alttext="negative 3.5" overflow="scroll"><mo>-</mo><mn>3.5</mn></math>

(c) The students correctly determine that the relationship between the angle of the ramp <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> and the acceleration of the cart is given by:

\(a=\frac{F_{\text{F}}}{m}-g\sin\theta\).

The students create a graph with <math alttext="sine of theta" overflow="scroll"><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi></math> plotted on the horizontal axis.

i. Indicate which measured or calculated quantity could be plotted on the vertical axis to yield a linear graph that could be used to calculate the force <math alttext="F sub F" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></msub></math> of the air on the fan-cart. Use the blank columns to list any quantities you will graph other than the data provided

Vertical axis: __________          Horizontal axis:<math alttext="sine of theta" overflow="scroll"><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi></math>

ii. On the graph shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>, plot the quantities indicated in part (c)(i) to create a graph that can be used to determine force <math alttext="F sub F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></msub></math> of the air on the fan-cart. Clearly label the vertical axis, including units.
iii. Draw a straight best-fit line for the data graphed in part (c) ii.

(d) Calculate the magnitude of the force <math alttext="F sub F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></msub></math> exerted on the fan-cart by the air using the best-fit line that you drew on Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> in part (c)(iii).

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
